Answers needed for University-community parking woes
By MICHEL STEVEN KRUG
It's 9:58 a.m on Monday
morning. You have a test in
Garland Hall at ten. Madly
driving through the parking lot
near the practice field, you
discover, as usual, that all parking
Spaces in the lot have already
been filled.
Logic would dictate traveling
to the lower lot near Wyman
Park Drive. But on this Monday
morning of mid-term
examinations, these spaces are
also filled. Thus, at 10:03, you
are forced to consider Charles
Village, St. Paul St., or University
Pkwy for prospective spots,
although this will mean an
additional five minutes. Finally
finding a precious plot on St.
Paul St., you arrive in class,
sweating and exasperated, at
10:15.

On-campus parking, free for
students, faculty members, and
University employees, is highly
competitive, especially for those
who don't arrive until 10:00 a.m.
Of course if one arrives before
9:00 there is little problem.
William Campbell, Director of
Plan-operations, said 1077 total
parking spaces are available on
campus, for those who possess
permits. Permits are issued to
those living outside a 34mile
radius of campus, a limit of two
cars per person. Of the 1077, 79
are metered spaces, 247 are
faculty spaces (type 1) and 751
are for students and university
employees (type 2). Over half of
the total parking spaces(564)are
located in the large parking lots
near the practice field.
In comparison to the number
of parking spaces available, the
number of parking permits issued

Larry Frelow takes over as University housing director
By BOB BUCHXNAN
Promising changes in the mode
of operation in the housing
office, Larry Frelow, formerly
assistant director of residential
life at the University of
Maryland, took over as director
here October 1.
The appointment of Frelow to
the housing directorship brings to
an end a long and extensive
search for a successor to Peter
Heist, who departed from his
post June 1 for a host of personal
considerations. The committee
charged with Frelow's selection
was headed by Dean of Students
Jakie Hall, and included several

students, including Student
„Council President Steve Ponchak.
Hall said that Frelow comes to
the housing post highly
_recommended and that both he
and the committee were very
impressed by the strong interest
in young people which they feel
Frelow possesses. "lie perceives
students as equals, he has good
business sense, and he also has a
strong management
background," the Dean said.
The new housing director
asserted that considerable
emphasis will be placed on the
need to incorporate student
input into the policy-making

decisions of his office. He
commented, "We will have alot
of student input. I will always
remember that the housing
office's main emphasis is to
provide a service to students, as
well as to the Hopkins
community." Frelow sees the
largest portion of this input to
come through dealings with the
student council.
The new director, who got his
start in student housing while
serving as a student assistant
housing director at Southern
University in Baton Rouge,
Louisiana, contrasted the setting
for student housing here with

that at the University of
Maryland: "At Maryland the
living student body is seven times
the size of the housing program
here. The major difference, in
addition to the size of the
housing programs, is the
apartment style of living offered
to upper classmen at Hopkins.
Frelow said that he has already
been briefed on the problems
which the University has
encountered in its dealings with
the community in the student
housing area. He said he will take
an active role in the relationship
between the community and
Hopkins. He voiced support for

the efforts of off-campus housing
diwtor Belva Scott to date,
saying "she has. sufficient
knowledge of what the problems
are within .the community
between students, and
landlords."
Frelow's resume is lengthy and
impressive. Eventually becoming
assistant director of housing at
Southern, he developed and
opened a freshman complex
which cost over $5 million.
He has been at
the University of Maryland for
the past four years, after leaving
Urbana following a two year
stay.

Socialist talks at MSE
Michael Harrington, former
chairman of the Socialist Party of
the United States, will speak
Tuesday, October 12, in Shriver
Hall for the Milton S. Eisenhower
Symposium. His topic:
"Freedom in the United States:
Ideal and Real Analysis of
Current United States Politics".
Harrington was a member of
t h e Task Force on Poverty
during President Johnson's
administration. Furthermore,
according to Crenson s Harrington
has lately been involved with the
Catholic Worker's Movement.
Paul Horowitz, co-chairman of
this year's MSE Symposium,
described Harrington as the
"leading leftist social critic." This
is an important reason he and H.
Nguyen, the other co-chairman
of the symposium, chose
Harrington to be their second
speaker. Another reason is
Harrington's recently published
critically-acclaimed book, The
Twilight of Capitalism.

Professor Matthew A. Crenson,
Political Science, feels that
Harrington has left a lasting
impact on the American people.
He alleged that President John F.
Kennedy was very much
impressed by Harrington's widely
read The Other America. Crenson
stated, "The Other America
provided the initial stimulus for
the creation of the Poverty
Program."
Next week, Horowitz and
Nguyen will present guest
lecturer Dr. Lewis Thomas,
president of the Memorial
Sloan-Kettering Cancer Institute
to speak on "The Creative and
Ethical Limitations of Science."
Thomas is expected to discuss
the creative process of scientific
discovery and its limitations. He
will debate whether the
government has any right to limit
research, especially in the field of
genetics, or whether the decision
should lie entirely with the
scientists themselves.

...Harrington has left a lasting impact on the American people.

Estelle Fishbein named Genera; Cc_nsel for University
By G.B. ZELINSKY
It should come as no surprise
to anyone, to learn that major
educational institutions such as
Johns Hopkins are in reality
corporate businesses. As such,
they are forced to develop
extensive ancillary staffs to deal
almost exclusively with the
non-academic or business side of
operating an 'academic
corporation.'
A vital concern of any
corporation's administration is a
sound legal support staff, and it
was in recognition of this need
that the Board of Trustees
established the position of
General Counsel of the
University last Au ust

From its inception, the post
has been held by Estelle A.
Fishbein, former Special
Assistant Attorney General for
the University of Maryland and a
specialist in university law.
In a recent interview, Fishbein
commented on the contemporary
'university-as-corporation.' "The
university is a large corporation,
and has all of the commercial
problems a corporation has. But
it is a unique organization in that
it has academic rather than
commercial values—a system of
ethics prevails."
Fishbein explained that in her
capacity as University attorney,
she handles a multitude of
roblems and responsibilities,_

ranging from campus labor
agreements to keeping abreast of
new statutes and regulations
which have an impact on
university operation. Having
served for three years as a Senior
Staff Attorney for the
Department of Health,
Education, and Welfare .(HEW),
Fishbein is well acquainted with
the intricacies of college- and
university law, and with the
controversial issue of federal
controls on higher education, in
particular. The federal
government (through HEW)
imposes admissions quotas and
curriculum guidelines on colleges,
as a prerequisite for federal
funding.

Corantion
Contending that, "the federal
intrusion into academics" had
"serious First Amendment
implications," Fishbein pointed
out that "the faculty of a school
is best qualified to determine the
academic policy of that school."
Fishbein claimed that
bureaucrats who are neither
qualified by education or
experience, should not "tell
schools what courses to teach, or
who to teach them to."
Acknowledgement
However, Fishbein
that "HEW
acknowledges

performs an important auditing
function, in seeking out and
preventing fraud and
misappropriation of federal
funds."
Graduate
A graduate of Yale Law
School, Fishbein described her
personal ideal for attorney-client
relationships as "preventive law."
"Law suits are not pleasant
things, and I feel that the greatest
service an attorney can perform
for a client, is to keep him out of
court."
Fishbein is aided by Assistant
General Counsel of the
University, Frederick DeKuyper.

Ground broken for Mudd buikling
By STEPHEN LEVIN
Groundb reaking • ceremonies
were held yesterday in Dunning
Park for the new biology building
planned for .that site.
ConStfuction of this building
marks the start of the new
Hopkins biology complex which
will include three buildings upon
completion.
Funds for the premier
structure, which has an estimated
cost of around $5 million, will
come mainly from a $1.5 million
contribution the University
received from the Seeley G.
Mudd Fund. The new building
will consequently be named in
Mudd's honor.
"1 am delighted by the
decision of the Seeley G. Mudd
Fund to contribute $1.5 million
toward the construction of a new
biology building, which will be
named in honor of Seeley G.
Mudd. Since its founding in

Swine flu innoculations to begin
The University Health
Service will begin distributing
swine flu shots "as soon as the
vaccine isavailable" even though
the Baltimore Civ health
dePartment ' as agreed to
innoculate college students and
their dependents at no cost.
"There are some people who
do not have personal positions or
who are unable 'n get off during
the hours posted by the city"
according to Betty Murdock,
assistant to the Vice-president for
Homewood Divisionsx xplaining
Why Hopkins! .•. seen fit to offer
its own flu shot effort. She added
that people without a means of
transportatioi might find it
difficult to gain access to the
vaccine.
However, it should he noted
that the public health . service,
Which began innoculation for
Phase one last Friday, designated
the Cathedral of Incarnation at
Charles Street and University
Parkway as an immunization
station, within -alking distance
of Homewood. Nurses there will
administer injections October 14
and 15 from 9 a.m. to 3:30 p.m.
and October 13 9:30 a.m. to 7

p.m. The first part of the plan is
designed to protect residents over
55 and adults and children with
chronic kidney, lung, and heart
diseases, such as emphysema.
Apparently, the decision about
implementing a University
innoculation- program has been
ill-conceived and administratively
flawed. Larry Denton, director of
administrative services conceded
that he attended "one meeting in
the summer as a representative of
George Benton, Vice-president
for Homewood Divisions, on the
health plan, but had since lost
contact with the program.
Jakie Hall, who as Dean of
students probably has the most
contact of all administrators with
undergraduates, admitted that he
still was not sure how the plan is
to be administered. "We have
been, talking about it for a while
with Dr. Torrey Brown and
others. I don't know where the
decision stands yet."
One hurdle that the University
now has to surmount is the
school's liability in providing
such services. Students will sign
waiver slips relieving the
University of responsibility

should illnesses result from the
innoculation.
According to Dr. Kathleen H.
Acree, co -coordinator of
Maryland's school program,
enough swine flu serum should
be available for all who desire it.
The Center for Disease Control,
based in Atlanta, Georgia, has
allocated approximately 4.1
million doses of the vaccine-3.5
million for healthy adults and
620,000 for high-risk residents.
A "bivalent vaccine" will be
distributed throughout October
in every Maryland county. One
need not be a resident of that
particular • subdivision to take
part in their immunization plan.
According to John Neff, who is
chief of pediatrics at City
Hospital, the "monovalent
vaccine" won't be available until
early October. He added that
people should not be alarmed
since no swine flu activity has
been evident thus far.
Neff explained that much o
the controversy surrounding th
production of the vaccine an
the implementation of a national
plan was due to the fact that
funds were diverted from other
public health efforts.

1876, Hopkins has enjoyed
worldwide recognition for its
programs of research in the life
sciences. There is at present,
however, a pressing need for
major' improvements in ,the
physical facilities for the
Department of Biology." noted
University President Steven
Muller.
"This magnificent grant is the
`go ahead' signal we wanted to
start construction on the first
building in a new biology
complex, whose completion will
help greatly to assure the
continued excellenc3 of Johns
Hopkins' program in the life
sciences." Muller concluded.
The building will provide space
for laboratories; classrooms,
faculty offices and support
facilities. Architecturally
speaking its design will be
modified Georgian in order to
relate to existing campus
structures.
Located on the north side of
the Homewood campus between
Macauley and Dunning Halls and
the Newton H. White Jr. Athletic
enter, the building will mark
the birth of a new quad on
campus; the Dunning quadrangle.
The building will extend over the
existing road which presently
comes up behind Dunning Park.
That road will be eliminated
completely, but the park itself
will just be relocated.
Muller noted that, "Of course
we want to keep a park so we
will landscape the area behind
the new building and in front of
the gymnasium. We plan to keep
the trees there, re-do and
improve the path, the bridge and
the tunnel and generally to
construct a very attractively
landscaped new park." In
addition the University received a
gift of seven animal sculptures by
the late Baniamino Bugano, a
prominent West Coast artist,
which' will be included in the new
park.
Robert Harvey, chairman of
the Hopkins' Board of Trustees,
noted that "The start of
construction on this building
marks the culmination of more
than a decade of planning. The
Johns Hopkins University's
biology department already is
recognized as one of the finest in

the country. These new facilities
will allow that position to be
maintained and strengthened."
Dr. William Harrington,
chairman of the biology
department radiated over his
department's new acquisition,
pointed out the space problems
in Mergenthaler Hall which was
constructed in 1941. He also
noted the advantages the building
offers all other disciplines on
campus especially with the
350-seat auditorium which is
included in plans for Mudd Hall.
The sponsoring Mudd Fund
was created in 1968 with funds
provided in Dr. Mudd's will. The
fund totals $44 million which is
to be given out over a period of
about 10 years to leading private
colleges and universities for new
buildings. With the Hopkins'
grant, the number of gifts totals
20 with funds in excess of $27
million.
Dr. Mudd graduated with a
degree jn mining engineering
from Columbia and went on to
Harvard Med School. He was
engaged in research dealing with
radiation and x-ray therapy at
Tech for 17 years before
serving as dean of the USC
School of Medicine. During his
lifetime, Mudd served as a trustee
of the Carnegie Institution of
Washington, D.C., USC,
Stanford, Cal Tech and Pomona
College. His contributions built
the Millikan Library at Cal Tech,
the Mudd Library at Pomona, the
von KleinSmid Center at USC
and the Mudd Laboratory on the
USC medical school campus.

dog's life
The other day, as one of the editors was walking about on
the lower quad, he chanced to see a german shepherd dog
eating a tree. No, really. After much discussion, it was
decided by the rest of the editorial board that this was an
omen. But of what?
The theory that, it had to do with.capitalist running dogs
was thrown out when it was discovered that the dog was a
democrat. There was also something about a nordic myth,
where this dog eats the universe, but nobody could remember
the dog's name. We also thought that maybe the dog was just
plain hungry, but that seemed too obvi9us.
We decided that the dog stood for communism, and that
the tree represented the fabric of American Life as we know
it. The conclusions were obvious. We have since dispatched a
search and destroy team to find this dog. If you know its
whereabouts, go there and kill it. It is, afterall, the American
thing to do.

People who makefraudulent phone calls
often getanother callfree.
Using someone else's credit card
or phone number, or using electronic
devices, may seem like a harmless prank.
But what it really is, is stealing.
And just like any other kind of theft,
it could lead to an arrest. A stiff fine. Or

even a jail sentence and a criminal record.
And no matter what else happened,
you'd still have to pay for all the calls you
made. So please don't make fraudulent
phone calls.
It just isn't worth the price.

Blue Jays post first win in contest with Ursinus Bears
Fighting not only a tough
opponent but adverse weather
conditions as well, the Blue Jay
football team recorded its first
victory of the season Saturday,
downing the Golden Bears of
Ursinus College 8-3 on the Bears
home turf in Collegeville,
Pennsylvania.
The lack of scoring in the
contest was due in a large part to
the swirling winds that engulfed
the field throughout the entire
game. These gusts made passing
nearly impossible and nullified
any semblance of a kicking game
on the part of either team.
As a result, strategies had to be
drastically readjusted as the
contest progressed. According to
Hopkins Head Coach Dennis
Cox, the Jays (now 1-2 for the
year) had hoped to put the ball
into the air at least thirty times
but, because of the winds, were
forced to resort to a ground

attack and attempted only
fourteen aerials.
Although neither team was
able to score in the first half, it
was rarely this climatic adversary
that was the major cause. Rather,
it was an old and more familiar
problem -turnovers -that kept
the game at 0-0 after two
quarters.
No less than seven fumbles and
interceptions were recorded by
both teams through the first
thirty minutes of play, bringing
possible scoring drives to
screeching halts.
The best opportunity to get
onto the scoreboard came just
seconds before the end of the
half. The Bears intercepted a
Blue Jay pass and returned the
ball to the JHU eight yard line.
However, the Hopkins defense
strengthened and a short field
goal attempt on the fourth down
was unsuccessful when the snap

was fumbled.
The Jays scored what proved
to be the winning points midway
through the third quarter. Under
the direction of quarterback Bob
Geist, Hopkins moved on the
ground to a first down at the
Ursinus fifteen.
On a third down and five
situation, Geist spotted tight end
Mike Rhodey over the middle
and rifled a pass to the senior
tri-captain. Without breaking
stride, Rhodey gathered in the
pass and rambled untouched into
the end zone for a 6-0 Hopkins
lead. Moments later, Geist
increased that lead to 8-0 as he
rolled around right end for the
two-point conversion.
The home team closed the gap
to 8-3 in the fourth quarter.
Beginning at their own
forty-four •, the Bears drove to a
first down at the Blue Jays
fifteen but could go no farther.

On fourth down, a field goal
attempt was good-the first such
successful try following three
previous failures.
Ursinus had one last gasp
remaining. With onlytwo minutes.
remaining in the game, the Bears
got the ball near midfield and
started to move. However a
fourth down pass at the Blue Jay
thirty-five fell incomplete and
Hopkins had its first win of the
season.
Coach Cox was obviously
pleased with the results of the
contest.
"The first win is always the
hardest," he commented. "I was
very pleased with our effort.
We've been involved in some
tough games and some teams
would have folded-I think this
shows alot of character."
"Our defense won the game
for us," the Blue Jay mentor
continued. "They did a great

job-especially when you realize
how long they were out there."
The Coach also cited the
efforts of Geist, the reserve
quarterback. According to Cox,
the team wasn't moving under
starter Torn Bender, "so
decided to give Bob an
opportunity and he was a big
spark for us."
The number of turnovers,
however, was disappointing to
the Coach.
"Two fumbles and two
interceptions are too manY
mistakes," he explained. "We
have to work to eliminate the
team-especiallY
offensive -mistakes."
The Jays will try to even their
record this Saturday at home
against Salisbury State. Game
time on Homewood Field is
2:00.

BIA is alive and well
By PHILIP GILLY
If you've ever been in Levering
around lunchtime some Friday
afternoon, you may remember
seeing some determined people
going into or coming out of the J
& H Rooms.
The group usually consists of
quite a few notable athletes,
several fraternity men, a couple
of scholarly types, and a lovely
young lady. This incongruous
assembly would certainly not be
expected to get along very well,
let alone direct an activity that
affects, and involves, more
students than even the Student
Council. Yet thisisprecisely what
happens during these weekly
meetings as this is the Board of
Intramural Athletics.
Each, year, the BIA sponsors
an intramural sports program
ranging from ping pong to
swimming to lacrosse. It has been
designed to provide organized
competition for the amateur
athletes among the male and
female undergraduates at
Hopkins.
For each event throughout the
year, points are awarded to the
victorious team. In May, the
dormitory and the fraternity
whose teams have amassed the
highest total of points are
awarded the BIA trophies.
The first sport organized this
year was Flag Football, which
got underway Sept. 20. It has

been difficult to schedule games
around all the rain that has
occurred recently, but after five
games, perennial powers Du and
Wilson-Wood are leading the frat
and dorm leagues respectively
with perfect records.
A surprising trend in recent
years is the increase in number
and ability of the independent
teams entering BIA tournaments.
This year is no exception, as the
Packers and the Black Student
Union currently hold third and
fourth places in the independent
division.
Two of the "minor sports"
have already been held. Pepper
White, riding for the Bicycle
Club, won the Bike Race for the
second year in a row, averaging
28 mph over the 7 mile course.
aking first place honors in the
11
/
2 mile Goucher Gallop was
Mike Massarelli.
The soccer tournament
announced for this past weekend
was completely flooded out and
will begin (hopefully) on Sat.,
Oct. 16. Entries are still being
accepted, so call Phil Gilly
(243-7069) for details.
Coming up in the next couple
of weeks will be Volleyball
(10/16), Billiards (10/30),
Bowling (11/6), and Gymnastics
(1 1/1 3). Remember, all BIA
sports are open to all undergrads
as either an independent, a dorm,
or a frat entry, so start planning
your teams now.

Larry Frelow takes over as University housing director
By BOB BUCHXNAN
Promising changes in the mode
of operation in the housing
office, Larry Frelow, formerly
assistant director of residential
life at the University of
Maryland, took over as director
here October 1.
The appointment of Frelow to
the housing directorship brings to
an end a long and extensive
search for a successor to Peter
Heist, who departed from his
post June 1 for a host of personal
considerations. The committee
charged with Frelow's selection
was headed by Dean of Students
Jakie Hall, and included several

students, including Student
„Council President Steve Ponchak.
Hall said that Frelow comes to
the housing post highly
_recommended and that both he
and the committee were very
impressed by the strong interest
in young people which they feel
Frelow possesses. "lie perceives
students as equals, he has good
business sense, and he also has a
strong management
background," the Dean said.
The new housing director
asserted that considerable
emphasis will be placed on the
need to incorporate student
input into the policy-making

decisions of his office. He
commented, "We will have alot
of student input. I will always
remember that the housing
office's main emphasis is to
provide a service to students, as
well as to the Hopkins
community." Frelow sees the
largest portion of this input to
come through dealings with the
student council.
The new director, who got his
start in student housing while
serving as a student assistant
housing director at Southern
University in Baton Rouge,
Louisiana, contrasted the setting
for student housing here with

that at the University of
Maryland: "At Maryland the
living student body is seven times
the size of the housing program
here. The major difference, in
addition to the size of the
housing programs, is the
apartment style of living offered
to upper classmen at Hopkins.
Frelow said that he has already
been briefed on the problems
which the University has
encountered in its dealings with
the community in the student
housing area. He said he will take
an active role in the relationship
between the community and
Hopkins. He voiced support for

the efforts of off-campus housing
diwtor Belva Scott to date,
saying "she has. sufficient
knowledge of what the problems
are within .the community
between students, and
landlords."
Frelow's resume is lengthy and
impressive. Eventually becoming
assistant director of housing at
Southern, he developed and
opened a freshman complex
which cost over $5 million.
He has been at
the University of Maryland for
the past four years, after leaving
Urbana following a two year
stay.

Socialist talks at MSE
Michael Harrington, former
chairman of the Socialist Party of
the United States, will speak
Tuesday, October 12, in Shriver
Hall for the Milton S. Eisenhower
Symposium. His topic:
"Freedom in the United States:
Ideal and Real Analysis of
Current United States Politics".
Harrington was a member of
t h e Task Force on Poverty
during President Johnson's
administration. Furthermore,
according to Crenson s Harrington
has lately been involved with the
Catholic Worker's Movement.
Paul Horowitz, co-chairman of
this year's MSE Symposium,
described Harrington as the
"leading leftist social critic." This
is an important reason he and H.
Nguyen, the other co-chairman
of the symposium, chose
Harrington to be their second
speaker. Another reason is
Harrington's recently published
critically-acclaimed book, The
Twilight of Capitalism.

Professor Matthew A. Crenson,
Political Science, feels that
Harrington has left a lasting
impact on the American people.
He alleged that President John F.
Kennedy was very much
impressed by Harrington's widely
read The Other America. Crenson
stated, "The Other America
provided the initial stimulus for
the creation of the Poverty
Program."
Next week, Horowitz and
Nguyen will present guest
lecturer Dr. Lewis Thomas,
president of the Memorial
Sloan-Kettering Cancer Institute
to speak on "The Creative and
Ethical Limitations of Science."
Thomas is expected to discuss
the creative process of scientific
discovery and its limitations. He
will debate whether the
government has any right to limit
research, especially in the field of
genetics, or whether the decision
should lie entirely with the
scientists themselves.

...Harrington has left a lasting impact on the American people.

Estelle Fishbein named Genera; Cc_nsel for University
By G.B. ZELINSKY
It should come as no surprise
to anyone, to learn that major
educational institutions such as
Johns Hopkins are in reality
corporate businesses. As such,
they are forced to develop
extensive ancillary staffs to deal
almost exclusively with the
non-academic or business side of
operating an 'academic
corporation.'
A vital concern of any
corporation's administration is a
sound legal support staff, and it
was in recognition of this need
that the Board of Trustees
established the position of
General Counsel of the
University last Au ust

From its inception, the post
has been held by Estelle A.
Fishbein, former Special
Assistant Attorney General for
the University of Maryland and a
specialist in university law.
In a recent interview, Fishbein
commented on the contemporary
'university-as-corporation.' "The
university is a large corporation,
and has all of the commercial
problems a corporation has. But
it is a unique organization in that
it has academic rather than
commercial values—a system of
ethics prevails."
Fishbein explained that in her
capacity as University attorney,
she handles a multitude of
roblems and responsibilities,_

ranging from campus labor
agreements to keeping abreast of
new statutes and regulations
which have an impact on
university operation. Having
served for three years as a Senior
Staff Attorney for the
Department of Health,
Education, and Welfare .(HEW),
Fishbein is well acquainted with
the intricacies of college- and
university law, and with the
controversial issue of federal
controls on higher education, in
particular. The federal
government (through HEW)
imposes admissions quotas and
curriculum guidelines on colleges,
as a prerequisite for federal
funding.

Corantion
Contending that, "the federal
intrusion into academics" had
"serious First Amendment
implications," Fishbein pointed
out that "the faculty of a school
is best qualified to determine the
academic policy of that school."
Fishbein claimed that
bureaucrats who are neither
qualified by education or
experience, should not "tell
schools what courses to teach, or
who to teach them to."
Acknowledgement
However, Fishbein
that "HEW
acknowledges

performs an important auditing
function, in seeking out and
preventing fraud and
misappropriation of federal
funds."
Graduate
A graduate of Yale Law
School, Fishbein described her
personal ideal for attorney-client
relationships as "preventive law."
"Law suits are not pleasant
things, and I feel that the greatest
service an attorney can perform
for a client, is to keep him out of
court."
Fishbein is aided by Assistant
General Counsel of the
University, Frederick DeKuyper.

Ground broken for Mudd buikling
By STEPHEN LEVIN
Groundb reaking • ceremonies
were held yesterday in Dunning
Park for the new biology building
planned for .that site.
ConStfuction of this building
marks the start of the new
Hopkins biology complex which
will include three buildings upon
completion.
Funds for the premier
structure, which has an estimated
cost of around $5 million, will
come mainly from a $1.5 million
contribution the University
received from the Seeley G.
Mudd Fund. The new building
will consequently be named in
Mudd's honor.
"1 am delighted by the
decision of the Seeley G. Mudd
Fund to contribute $1.5 million
toward the construction of a new
biology building, which will be
named in honor of Seeley G.

Swine flu innoculations to begin
The University Health
Service will begin distributing
swine flu shots "as soon as the
vaccine isavailable" even though
the Baltimore Civ health
dePartment ' as agreed to
innoculate college students and
their dependents at no cost.
"There are some people who
do not have personal positions or
who are unable 'n get off during
the hours posted by the city"
according to Betty Murdock,
assistant to the Vice-president for
Homewood Divisionsx xplaining
Why Hopkins! .•. seen fit to offer
its own flu shot effort. She added
that people without a means of
transportatioi might find it
difficult to gain access to the
vaccine.
However, it should he noted
that the public health . service,
Which began innoculation for
Phase one last Friday, designated
the Cathedral of Incarnation at
Charles Street and University
Parkway as an immunization
station, within -alking distance
of Homewood. Nurses there will
administer injections October 14
and 15 from 9 a.m. to 3:30 p.m.
and October 13 9:30 a.m. to 7

p.m. The first part of the plan is
designed to protect residents over
55 and adults and children with
chronic kidney, lung, and heart
diseases, such as emphysema.
Apparently, the decision about
implementing a University
innoculation- program has been
ill-conceived and administratively
flawed. Larry Denton, director of
administrative services conceded
that he attended "one meeting in
the summer as a representative of
George Benton, Vice-president
for Homewood Divisions, on the
health plan, but had since lost
contact with the program.
Jakie Hall, who as Dean of
students probably has the most
contact of all administrators with
undergraduates, admitted that he
still was not sure how the plan is
to be administered. "We have
been, talking about it for a while
with Dr. Torrey Brown and
others. I don't know where the
decision stands yet."
One hurdle that the University
now has to surmount is the
school's liability in providing
such services. Students will sign
waiver slips relieving the
University of responsibility

should illnesses result from the
innoculation.
According to Dr. Kathleen H.
Acree, co -coordinator of
Maryland's school program,
enough swine flu serum should
be available for all who desire it.
The Center for Disease Control,
based in Atlanta, Georgia, has
allocated approximately 4.1
million doses of the vaccine-3.5
million for healthy adults and
620,000 for high-risk residents.
A "bivalent vaccine" will be
distributed throughout October
in every Maryland county. One
need not be a resident of that
particular • subdivision to take
part in their immunization plan.
According to John Neff, who is
chief of pediatrics at City
Hospital, the "monovalent
vaccine" won't be available until
early October. He added that
people should not be alarmed
since no swine flu activity has
been evident thus far.
Neff explained that much o
the controversy surrounding th
production of the vaccine an
the implementation of a national
plan was due to the fact that
funds were diverted from other
public health efforts.

1876, Hopkins has enjoyed
worldwide recognition for its
programs of research in the life
sciences. There is at present,
however, a pressing need for
major' improvements in ,the
physical facilities for the
Department of Biology." noted
University President Steven
Muller.
"This magnificent grant is the
`go ahead' signal we wanted to
start construction on the first
building in a new biology
complex, whose completion will
help greatly to assure the
continued excellenc3 of Johns
Hopkins' program in the life
sciences." Muller concluded.
The building will provide space
for laboratories; classrooms,
faculty offices and support
facilities. Architecturally
speaking its design will be
modified Georgian in order to
relate to existing campus
structures.
Located on the north side of
the Homewood campus between
Macauley and Dunning Halls and
the Newton H. White Jr. Athletic
enter, the building will mark
the birth of a new quad on
campus; the Dunning quadrangle.
The building will extend over the
existing road which presently
comes up behind Dunning Park.
That road will be eliminated
completely, but the park itself
will just be relocated.
Muller noted that, "Of course
we want to keep a park so we
will landscape the area behind
the new building and in front of
the gymnasium. We plan to keep
the trees there, re-do and
improve the path, the bridge and
the tunnel and generally to
construct a very attractively
landscaped new park." In
addition the University received a
gift of seven animal sculptures by
the late Baniamino Bugano, a
prominent West Coast artist,
which' will be included in the new
park.
Robert Harvey, chairman of
the Hopkins' Board of Trustees,
noted that "The start of
construction on this building
marks the culmination of more
than a decade of planning. The
Johns Hopkins University's
biology department already is
recognized as one of the finest in

the country. These new facilities
will allow that position to be
maintained and strengthened."
Dr. William Harrington,
chairman of the biology
department radiated over his
department's new acquisition,
pointed out the space problems
in Mergenthaler Hall which was
constructed in 1941. He also
noted the advantages the building
offers all other disciplines on
campus especially with the
350-seat auditorium which is
included in plans for Mudd Hall.
The sponsoring Mudd Fund
was created in 1968 with funds
provided in Dr. Mudd's will. The
fund totals $44 million which is
to be given out over a period of
about 10 years to leading private
colleges and universities for new
buildings. With the Hopkins'
grant, the number of gifts totals
20 with funds in excess of $27
million.
Dr. Mudd graduated with a
degree jn mining engineering
from Columbia and went on to
Harvard Med School. He was
engaged in research dealing with
radiation and x-ray therapy at
Tech for 17 years before
serving as dean of the USC
School of Medicine. During his
lifetime, Mudd served as a trustee
of the Carnegie Institution of
Washington, D.C., USC,
Stanford, Cal Tech and Pomona
College. His contributions built
the Millikan Library at Cal Tech,
the Mudd Library at Pomona, the
von KleinSmid Center at USC
and the Mudd Laboratory on the
USC medical school campus.

dog's life
The other day, as one of the editors was walking about on
the lower quad, he chanced to see a german shepherd dog
eating a tree. No, really. After much discussion, it was
decided by the rest of the editorial board that this was an
omen. But of what?
The theory that, it had to do with.capitalist running dogs
was thrown out when it was discovered that the dog was a
democrat. There was also something about a nordic myth,
where this dog eats the universe, but nobody could remember
the dog's name. We also thought that maybe the dog was just
plain hungry, but that seemed too obvi9us.
We decided that the dog stood for communism, and that
the tree represented the fabric of American Life as we know
it. The conclusions were obvious. We have since dispatched a
search and destroy team to find this dog. If you know its
whereabouts, go there and kill it. It is, afterall, the American
thing to do.

Blue Jays post first win in contest with Ursinus Bears
Fighting not only a tough
opponent but adverse weather
conditions as well, the Blue Jay
football team recorded its first
victory of the season Saturday,
downing the Golden Bears of
Ursinus College 8-3 on the Bears
home turf in Collegeville,
Pennsylvania.
The lack of scoring in the
contest was due in a large part to
the swirling winds that engulfed
the field throughout the entire
game. These gusts made passing
nearly impossible and nullified
any semblance of a kicking game
on the part of either team.
As a result, strategies had to be
drastically readjusted as the
contest progressed. According to
Hopkins Head Coach Dennis
Cox, the Jays (now 1-2 for the
year) had hoped to put the ball
into the air at least thirty times
but, because of the winds, were
forced to resort to a ground

attack and attempted only
fourteen aerials.
Although neither team was
able to score in the first half, it
was rarely this climatic adversary
that was the major cause. Rather,
it was an old and more familiar
problem -turnovers -that kept
the game at 0-0 after two
quarters.
No less than seven fumbles and
interceptions were recorded by
both teams through the first
thirty minutes of play, bringing
possible scoring drives to
screeching halts.
The best opportunity to get
onto the scoreboard came just
seconds before the end of the
half. The Bears intercepted a
Blue Jay pass and returned the
ball to the JHU eight yard line.
However, the Hopkins defense
strengthened and a short field
goal attempt on the fourth down
was unsuccessful when the snap

was fumbled.
The Jays scored what proved
to be the winning points midway
through the third quarter. Under
the direction of quarterback Bob
Geist, Hopkins moved on the
ground to a first down at the
Ursinus fifteen.
On a third down and five
situation, Geist spotted tight end
Mike Rhodey over the middle
and rifled a pass to the senior
tri-captain. Without breaking
stride, Rhodey gathered in the
pass and rambled untouched into
the end zone for a 6-0 Hopkins
lead. Moments later, Geist
increased that lead to 8-0 as he
rolled around right end for the
two-point conversion.
The home team closed the gap
to 8-3 in the fourth quarter.
Beginning at their own
forty-four •, the Bears drove to a
first down at the Blue Jays
fifteen but could go no farther.

On fourth down, a field goal
attempt was good-the first such
successful try following three
previous failures.
Ursinus had one last gasp
remaining. With onlytwo minutes.
remaining in the game, the Bears
got the ball near midfield and
started to move. However a
fourth down pass at the Blue Jay
thirty-five fell incomplete and
Hopkins had its first win of the
season.
Coach Cox was obviously
pleased with the results of the
contest.
"The first win is always the
hardest," he commented. "I was
very pleased with our effort.
We've been involved in some
tough games and some teams
would have folded-I think this
shows alot of character."
"Our defense won the game
for us," the Blue Jay mentor
continued. "They did a great

job-especially when you realize
how long they were out there."
The Coach also cited the
efforts of Geist, the reserve
quarterback. According to Cox,
the team wasn't moving under
starter Torn Bender, "so
decided to give Bob an
opportunity and he was a big
spark for us."
The number of turnovers,
however, was disappointing to
the Coach.
"Two fumbles and two
interceptions are too manY
mistakes," he explained. "We
have to work to eliminate the
team-especiallY
offensive -mistakes."
The Jays will try to even their
record this Saturday at home
against Salisbury State. Game
time on Homewood Field is
2:00.

BIA is alive and well
By PHILIP GILLY
If you've ever been in Levering
around lunchtime some Friday
afternoon, you may remember
seeing some determined people
going into or coming out of the J
& H Rooms.
The group usually consists of
quite a few notable athletes,
several fraternity men, a couple
of scholarly types, and a lovely
young lady. This incongruous
assembly would certainly not be
expected to get along very well,
let alone direct an activity that
affects, and involves, more
students than even the Student
Council. Yet thisisprecisely what
happens during these weekly
meetings as this is the Board of
Intramural Athletics.
Each, year, the BIA sponsors
an intramural sports program
ranging from ping pong to
swimming to lacrosse. It has been
designed to provide organized
competition for the amateur
athletes among the male and
female undergraduates at
Hopkins.
For each event throughout the
year, points are awarded to the
victorious team. In May, the
dormitory and the fraternity
whose teams have amassed the
highest total of points are
awarded the BIA trophies.
The first sport organized this
year was Flag Football, which
got underway Sept. 20. It has

been difficult to schedule games
around all the rain that has
occurred recently, but after five
games, perennial powers Du and
Wilson-Wood are leading the frat
and dorm leagues respectively
with perfect records.
A surprising trend in recent
years is the increase in number
and ability of the independent
teams entering BIA tournaments.
This year is no exception, as the
Packers and the Black Student
Union currently hold third and
fourth places in the independent
division.
Two of the "minor sports"
have already been held. Pepper
White, riding for the Bicycle
Club, won the Bike Race for the
second year in a row, averaging
28 mph over the 7 mile course.
aking first place honors in the
11
/
2 mile Goucher Gallop was
Mike Massarelli.
The soccer tournament
announced for this past weekend
was completely flooded out and
will begin (hopefully) on Sat.,
Oct. 16. Entries are still being
accepted, so call Phil Gilly
(243-7069) for details.
Coming up in the next couple
of weeks will be Volleyball
(10/16), Billiards (10/30),
Bowling (11/6), and Gymnastics
(1 1/1 3). Remember, all BIA
sports are open to all undergrads
as either an independent, a dorm,
or a frat entry, so start planning
your teams now.

JHU stickmen whip ex-laxers and UNC
The Blue Jay Fall Lacrosse
team opened its schedule this
past weekend with a pair of
performances that Hopkins fans
hope will be indicative of team
play in the spring.
Saturday night, the Jays
defeated a team composed of
JHU alumni stickmen,. 18-8,
while Sunday afternoon saw
Hopkins down a stubborn team
of Tar Heels from the University
of North Carolina, 10-4.
The purpose of the fall
lacrosse program is severalfold.
First, it enables spring players!
who don't compete,in other fall
sports to stay in top physical
shape. It also lets coaches get an
advance look at the incoming
freshmen and allows these
first-year players to begin to

become indoctrinated into the
Blue Jay lacrosse system.
The contest on Saturday
evoked many memories for those
fans who braved the plumetting
temperatures and high winds.
Among the featured players
competing for the Alumni team
were former Blue Jay
All-Americans Jack Thomas,
Rick Kowalchuk and Dale
Kohler.
The present Jays, however,
broke quickly into the lead as
attackman Frank ,Cutrone scored
in the game's first ninety
seconds. Thomas, demonstrating
to the crowd that he had lost
little in the past three years,
countered with the Alumni's first
goal a minute later.
The game continued to be an
evenly matched affair throughout
much of the first half. A string of
three consecutive goals gave the
Alumni a 5-4 lead midway
through the second quarter, but a
trio of scores from the present
Blue • Jays late in the period
produced a 7-5 halftime bulge
and a lead they would never
relinquish.
Following the third quarter, it
was still a wide open game as the
Fall team held only a 10-7
advantage. However, the contest
became a rout in the final stanza
as the current Jays notched eight
goals en route to the 18-8 final score.
Performers
Key performers for the Fall

stickmen included Jon Swerdloff
(five goals), Jim Bione. (four
goals), Kevin Kilner (one goal
and three assists) and Cutrone
(three goals). Thomas led the
Alumni with three scores.
The contest against North
Carolina was marked by'
outstanding goaltending and a
solid all-around defense. After
allowing a pair of Tar Heel scores
in the first period, the Blue Jays
closed the gate and did not allow
another UNC goal until late in
the fourth quarter.
In the meantime, the Jays,
after holding a 3-2 halftime lead,
had reeled off seven unanswered
goals to salt away their second
victory in less than twenty-four
hours. Once again, Swerdloff led
the offensive charge, racking up
two goals and two assists for his
afternoon's work.
Blue Jay head Coach Henry
Ciccarone was happy with the
team's opening efforts.
"Considering we've had only
seven practices in about two
weeks and we have lots of new
guys, I was very pleased," the
lacrosse mentor commented.
"The thing I was especially
pleased with in both scrimmages
was our defense-not just our
close defense, but our overall
defense including the middies."
"But,' Ciccarone concluded,
"we'll find out about our defense
this Friday against UMBC-they
beat Maryland in a scrimmage
and have an excellent attack."
